name: 2-hexynoic acid
Reason: The compound 2-hexynoic acid consists of several functional groups and structural features that influence its melting point. Starting with pentanoic acid, which has a melting point of around -34.5, we consider the following modifications: 1) Adding an additional carbon to the alkyl chain should increase the melting point minimally by about 3-5 degrees due to increased van der Waals interactions. 2) Introducing a triple bond (alkyne) in the compound will slightly raise the melting point due to the linear geometry and potential for dipole alignment, estimated around +5 degrees. However, the rigidity and linearity might also limit close packing, mitigating some of the increase. 3) The presence of the carboxylic acid group contributes significantly to the melting point through hydrogen bonding. Given that pentanoic acid is the base molecule, replacing one of its -CH2- groups with the carboxyl group should create a substantial increase, estimated around +60 degrees considering the dimerization of carboxylic acids in solid state due to hydrogen bonding. Therefore, combining these effects together, we get an estimated increase of 68-70 degrees from the base pentanoic acid melting point.
